pr_title: [Test] Disable the timeout setting on RISC-V

timeline.bodyText: This is going to break Linux.
timeline.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: Nope, the change was verified on personal builds (including all platforms)
replies.author: ChengJin01

replies.bodyText: If you are concerned with the potential issue,  we can add the check to ensure it only exists on RISC-V.
replies.author: ChengJin01

replies.bodyText:
When cl is UNIXProcess, if (!(true) || !(false)) or if (false || true) is always true, so on Linux it will return 0. This code is only used when a timeout occurs, so a test would have to hang in order to see it no longer works on Unix.

we can add the check to ensure it only exists on RISC-V.

this would be better
replies.author: pshipton

timeline.message:
[Test] Disable JIT & the timeout setting on RISC-V

The code change is to disable JIT in test code
and disable the timeout setting due to the lack
of JIT on RISC-V.

Signed-off-by: Cheng Jin <jincheng@ca.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText: The check against ProcessImpl is not needed and is confusing, pls use if (!cl.getName().equals("java.lang.UNIXProcess") || isRiscv)
timeline.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: Agree and fixed in this way.
replies.author: ChengJin01

Signed-off-by: Cheng Jin <jincheng@ca.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText: Is it better to change the default timeout when testing on riscv rather than modifying the test framework?
timeline.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: Currently the idea of the code is looping out there by setting up the fixed time (which is always > 0) to get the test involved to complete.  I am not sure what the default timeout is gonna be as it is hard to anticipate how long it takes to finish.
replies.author: ChengJin01

replies.bodyText: The default could be set arbitrarily large, such as 24 hours or anything that makes sense.
replies.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText:
Will try to change the code  at /test/functional/cmdline_options_tester/src/TestConfigParser.java
String timeout = (String)attributes.get("timeout");
_currentTest = new Test( id, timeout, _debugCmdOnTimeout ); <--- change it for risc-v

to see how it goes this way.
replies.author: ChengJin01

timeline.message:
[Test] Disable the timeout setting on RISC-V

The code change is to disable the timeout setting
due to the lack of JIT on RISC-V.

Signed-off-by: Cheng Jin <jincheng@ca.ibm.com>

[Test] Disable the timeout setting on RISC-V

The code change is to disable the timeout setting
due to the lack of JIT on RISC-V.

Signed-off-by: Cheng Jin <jincheng@ca.ibm.com>

timeline.bodyText: Seems a little excessive for a single test to run for 10 days.
timeline.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: It won't be necessary in most of cases. The idea is to simply disable the timer to some extent to ensure we cover all test cases in /test/functional/cmdLineTests. (e.g. DDR related test which runs extremely slow on the hardware and even worse on the emulator).
replies.author: ChengJin01

replies.bodyText: Ok, but the timeout is for an individual command line test, not a suite of tests. How long does the DDR test take?
replies.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: Yes, that's we expect to do for individual tests.  According to my previous experience, it took from a couple of hours to half of a day to finish, depending on the size of the generated core dumps.
replies.author: ChengJin01

replies.bodyText: Then you can use something like 16 hours for the timeout, rather than 10 days.
replies.author: pshipton

replies.bodyText: Updated to 16 hours as suggested. We still have a chance to adjust in the future if any issue with timeout is detected in there.
replies.author: ChengJin01
